author: s1na
content: The PRs on `ethereum/execution-apis` are not getting a lot of love. I do think substantial changes to the API specs would benefit from the EIP format.

author: s1na
content:
Plus execution-apis has no good way to convey semantics. This is why for eth_simulateV1 we had to add a md doc to express a lot of nuances
https://github.com/ethereum/execution-apis/pull/484/files#diff-1e4727bbfb75c5cc85054abbf972a1cd472e9e512a9d8bbc8152210a0062182b

author: lightclient
content:
EIP PRs also aren't getting a lot of love ðŸ˜…  I really dont think EIP format makes sense for APIs because they change and once you start layering the changes on, it's difficult to tell what the latest state is. That's why we've moved to specs-style definition with consensus-specs, execution-specs, execution-apis, etc. 

I think the execution-apis repo can definitely use love, but im not sure how we can better specify complex rpcs like eth_simulate without some executable spec.

author: s1na
content: Hah need more love to go around. So taking the engine API as an example, in the paris version there was quite a lot of semantics documentation. In following forks it is more barebone, mostly adding fields. I think a similar model can make sense where an initial document outlines the rationale and semantics and after that the specs-style definition is kept up-to-date. It is after all something that clients have to agree on, unlike say something like a flag.

author: kclowes
content: Are you suggesting maintaining an EIP-style repo and the current spec definition once things have been agreed on?

author: s1na
content: I don't think another repo people have to watch out for is productive. I am suggesting an EIP for substantial new methods with rationale and semantics to reach consensus between clients and formalizing it in openrpc for future changes. It is not every day that we add a new method outside the scope of a consensus change.
